efex5c0.Author: xelephonte
efex5c0.Text:
Feeling very bearish on Bitcoin. Here’s why?

Obviously, the past 7 days is not a good indicator of anything. It’s been Bart Simpson’ing. I am feeling very bearish on BTC (though I stay HODLing) because of this halvening. Miners are going to hit half the reward for mining a block of BTC which I think will only create anxiety and fear among whales. The whales see no momentum and they are the drivers behind the cryptocurrency market. Combine that with halvening and I can see utter chaos for the next couple weeks. Of course, old man Crytogrip will come around to tout his Bakkt which he has been doing since July but Bakkt remains a figment of the imagination. Halvening is here and I wouldn’t be surprised if the entire market fails to $60 bill. The whales could be create a bull trap the past 2 days and following the next couple days. I could see BTC fall to $1700. Not trying to create FUD but this halvening process complicate things. Let me know if you agree/disagree...

efee54a.Author: tommygunz007
efee54a.Text: If Venezuela converted their economy to Bitcoin when it was $20,000 they would be near bankrupt right now.. oh wait..

eff6mcn.Author: xelephonte
eff6mcn.Text: Does anybody in here that a recession could have no impact on Bitcoin? We know that a gust of wind impacts Bitcoin these days let alone a recession or Great Depression. I’m so convinced that a recession could have nothing but devastating impacts on Bitcoin that I would be absolutely shocked if Bitcoin surged during a terrible economy. But, I’m not a psychic and I could be very wrong. A recession is very ominous for many things except for investing in bargain stores like Dollartree and Walmart (since everyone is broke). Bitcoin is yet to be tested by a bad economy since it was created after the last recession. This is a test I’m very curious about. Assume the worst, hope for the best.

efcyygg.Author: The-Physicist
efcyygg.Text:
So a lot of people will probably be reporting capital losses from crypto on their tax returns during the next few months.  Many of those will likely receive nice tax refunds as a result. 

I wonder if they will put a nice size chunk of that refund back into crypto at these fire sale prices.  This is what I’m planning to do (from my trading stack). If so, this could help stabilize the market for a while until Fidelity custody solutions and Bakkt kick into gear in a few months.

efcjplf.Text: Difficult, even though the BTC price is known for surprises, the buyer sentiment right now is cautious. That feeling is going to prevail for a while, unless 2019 has an ace upon its sleeve (excellent news that boosts sentiment).

it all works out in the wash if you dont buy a lump sum as an "investment".  DCA

efcnydu.Author: curseknight
efcnydu.Text:
I wouldn't be concerned about price crashes. If they come, so be it. I believe in what the currency stands for and I have the strong feeling it will appreciate in the long run. 
What I can logically state about the present situation is that only a buyer under $3.4k can profit by selling now. Similarly only a buyer under $3k can profit by bringing it down there. And I strongly believe someone who is at a loss and has not sold by now would hardly do so from now on. Hope my two cents helped.

efcw56n.Author: cryptogrip
efcw56n.Text: Absolutely nothing. It's speculation fueled by shitty clickbait articles. Selling is becoming more and more exhausted and if we have not already hit bottom, then it's likely close. When you read all that crap about bitcoin going down way further, it's efforts of manipulation. And it doesn't just occur in the downward direction either - when headlines were calling for 100k by the end of 2018, that too was clickbait and manipulation. The best strategy is, and has always been, follow developments in the space, use common sense, and buy small amounts at a time to keep your average buy in check.

efdwofm.Author: The-Physicist
efdwofm.Text:
Yeah that’s the max amount they can claim as a refund, but there are tax advantages to offsetting any other capital gains they have with their total crypto losses. 

$3k per person * 1000s of people is something. With this low volume it is somewhat helpful to prop up the market until something good comes along.

efgncvh.Author: xelephonte
efgncvh.Text: Arguably the most idiotic thing the Physicist has said yet. He leaped into Crytogrip territory. He clearly did not know about the $3,000 limit of capital losses which is only for married people. For single people or married people that file as single, the most you can claim is $1,500. This is something I absolutely hate about the tax system. It’s designed for you to get fucked. They get 50% on your capital gains but you can only claim $1,500 on capital losses. How messed up is that. But, it’s hilarious to think that people really want to invest in Shitcoin after having just suffered massive losses. Take your tax refund and buy Bitcoin just so you can lose more money? I think not.

efd100p.Author: The-Physicist
efd100p.Text: No. You would have had to sell to realize a capital loss.

efeixed.Author: gretteaj

effcyvn.Author: AussieBitcoiner
effcyvn.Text:
I think there's a good argument for it. In running a node I've been surprised just how much data is used. Maintaining decentralisation has to be the first priority, as Luke says if you can't maintain decentralisation then there is no point in what we're doing here.

IMO there are currently bigger reasons than data/computer resources as to why many don't set up nodes, mainly that many just don't see/understand its importance. It can take time to really appreciate what a node does and how you need to be running one in order to be using bitcoin with no trust. But if chain growth continues to out-do tech growth, that side of it could certainly become more pressing in the future.

I don't think we could ever see a block size reduction now though, it would be almost impossible to achieve consensus on it unless the number of nodes gets dangerously low.

efejqsn.Author: cryptogrip
efejqsn.Text: Ha ha, I hear ya. It's almost as though some said to these naysayers "here's 10 years of data for you...now go be an idiot and just look at the last one to draw your conclusion:. :)

efhqv3u.Author: aidanlister
efhqv3u.Text:
@gretteaj transaction volume is going down (see the chart I just posted), and there's only 5M wallets with more than 0.01 BTC in them ... this does not look good.

More importantly, there's no reason for your average American to adopt BTC. There's been plenty of advances in payments that have simply been ignored by the bulk of the US public, eg contactless payments (apple pay, etc) and these are clear, obvious improvements. BTC is not a clear improvement, so what exactly is going to drive the price up?

efe2zt8.Author: GreenStretch
efe2zt8.Text: "You really stepped in something good this time!" Cousin Balki

efhrb7x.Author: aidanlister
efhrb7x.Text:
And you're looking at the first 9 and drawing another ... both approaches are stupid.

The first point is to recognise that no one knows. The second is realising that no one gets rich of a get rich scheme the second time around. It shot up due to speculation, if it's ever going to beat its ATH it'll be on fundamentals not speculation, and the fundamentals don't look great.

efhwoqt.Author: cryptogrip
efhwoqt.Text: Anyone looking to get rich has likely moved on by now. But for making some gains on your money, including bitcoin in the high risk portion of your investments in the case that this thing continues to grow as it has been for a decade is not a bad move by any means. No, I don't agree with looking at only the first 9 years. To make an assessment using data, ALL the data must be used. Price will be up and down for a long time, but the building of a crypto ecosystem with bitcoin as the crown jewel has been VERY consistent and increasing over time. Anyone that thinks this is all going to stop being built at this point is most certainly not looking at all the data.
